Award.AwardTitle: Workforce Panel and Workshop Joint Mathematical Meeting - January 2011
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for a workshop and panel, Good Intentions Are Necessary but Not Sufficient: Steps Toward Best Practices in Mentoring Underrepresented Students, at the January 2011 Joint Mathematics Meeting, to be held in New Orleans. The panel will address broadening participation in the mathematical sciences. The panel is comprised of experts who share a deep commitment to ensuring diversity in the mathematical sciences. The primary goal is to discuss ideas for programs that will bring underrepresented students into mathematics.

The organizers seek to attract participants from a diverse set of institutions to the workshop. An additional goal is to bring together a broad and diverse group of stakeholders and critical consumers in order to help more mathematical scientists become aware of developments in the discipline. A fundamental understanding is that good intentions are necessary but not sufficient when taking steps toward best practices in mentoring under-represented students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DMS Workforce Panel and Workshop Joint Mathematical Meeting—January 2011

A panel and workshop focused on increasing diversity among undergraduate and graduate students in the mathematical sciences was held at the January 2011 Joint Mathematics Meeting (JMM) in New Orleans. Panel members included NSF-supported principal investigators from a diverse group of institutions that have developed effective mentoring programs. The goals of the panel and the workshop were to: inform mathematics professionals about the NSF Division of Mathematical Science Workforce efforts focused on students; increase awareness of existing strategic interventions that have proven successful in attracting and retaining underrepresented students in mathematics; and generate new ideas for achieving inclusivity. Panel members included:

• James Curry, Panel Chair and PI, University of Colorado Boulder, PI of EMSW21-MCTP: Colorado Advantage

• Carlos Castillo-Chavez, Arizona State University

• A. G. (Loek) Helminch, North Carolina State University, PI of EMSW21-MCTP: Institute for Mathematics at North Carolina State (I'M at State), PI of the Alliance for Building Faculty Diversity in the Mathematical Sciences

• Rhonda Hughes, Bryn Mawr College, PI of the EDGE Program

• Philip Kutzko, University of Iowa, co-PI of the AGEP: Iowa Alliance for Graduate Education and Professoriate and Recipient of the Presidential Award for Excellence and Mentoring

• Werner Horn, California State University, Northridge, former PI of EMSW21-MCTP PUMP: Preparing Undergraduates through Mentoring towards PhDs

The workshop included between 30 and 40 JMM attendees.

At the University of Colorado, information gained from the panel and workshop helped to accelerate efforts to develop and implement initiatives that would make undergraduate engineering programs (including the Department of Applied Mathematics) more inclusive for underrepresented students. To be directly admitted into the College of Engineering, students must demonstrate readiness for college calculus, and must successfully complete two semesters of calculus in the first year. When this requirement was found to eliminate underrepresented students who demonstrated high potential and motivation but insufficient high school preparation, the Broadening Opportunities through Leadership and Diversity (BOLD) Center initiated a 5-year Gold Shirt program in 2009, modeled after red-shirting programs in college athletics but named for a school color. Each year, the College awards 30 Gold Shirt scholarships to a group of carefully selected students; about two-thirds of students in each cohort are underrepresented minorities, and about half are first-generation college students. During their first year, Gold Shirt students enroll in pre-calculus courses (offered by the Department of Applied Mathematics, with a general engineering course number GEEN 1235) and science classes to prepare them for the engineering curriculum. They also take an introductory engineering design course with regularly admitted freshmen.

Because of the success of the Gold Shirt program (in fall 2013, the first graduate of the Gold Shirt earned summa cum laude honors in civil engineering), the College of Engineering created a Pre-Engineering Program to offer a pathway to engineering degrees to students who do not traditionally meet the minimum engineering admissions requirements. The pre-calculus class offered by the Department of Applied Mathematics for the Gold Shirt Program participants has become available to all students in the Pre-Engineering Program, and the course number has been changed from General Engineering 1235 to Applied Mathematics 1235.
